Brilliant question, but actually the first question to ask is "is the net part of the spider's body?". The commentary implicitly says it isn't, because quotes scientists claiming that a spider's mind extends out of its body into the net. But actually it is. The net comes out from the spider's body, goes back into it if eaten, is always in contact with other body parts for the whole of its existence. It is by all means part of the spider's nervous system, carrying sensorial input to the brain. It actually constitutes part, perhaps the totality , of the proprioceptive word a spider lives in, and is the only interface the spider has with the outside word, for, as we are are taught, a spider is blind.

The philosophers Andy Clark and David Chalmers formulated the "Extended Mind Thesis" which (roughly) states that objects and processes external to our bodies may be able to count as part of our mind. For example, things like notebooks and cellphones aren't between our ears, but they aid in memory and retrieval of information and thus, are vital to our cognition and maybe even constitute part of the mind. This video sort of presents a spider based version of that idea.

I find REAL hard to believe that the web is a part of their minds. AFAIK, spider webs don't have any sort of internet nervous system. I think it's easier to assume their mental mapping skills come from place cells, neurons that fire when either the animal or a nearby object is in a certain location, or an invertebrate place cell analog. Place cells are fascinating.

Why did you wait until the last part of the video to mention the mind part? There was literally no explanation. All that was said was scientists believe, and there was not research mentioned to support the claim.

You guys bring information on these wonderful creatures we live with such charm, It's caused me to lose my irrational fear of them! I don't go out of my way to kill them in my house like I used to. I just imagine their cute little faces when I see them and wave at them or check them out since they're quite curious. I found out I have a lot of jumping spiders in my house, so a double bonus on the cute! Thank you guys so much for what you do!!

Random fact that is probably not important to you: I have a tiny spider who I rescued from our bathroom and I named it Pepsi. We feed him ants and I love him :)

Update: Pepsi is doing great and has shed his skin 2 times I think! He is a big boi now! Also I found another spider at the exact same spot that he was in! I think I'm going to name that one Arachne :)

Sad update: After about half a year together, Pepsi passed away. I just went to feed him, and he was dead. I think he died because of old age, but I'm really sad. Arachne is gone too, although they died a few weeks after I started feeding them. I hope they rest in piece.

I was just thinking this a few weeks ago when watching a giant orb weaver finish it's web near a porch light. I assumed they built them on instinct.
